Utterance: Hi again! It’s nice to see you. How have you been since we last met?
Hi, Ellie! I’ve been doing well. I tried the breathing exercises we talked about.
That’s great to hear! How did it go for you?
It helped a lot, especially before conversations. I felt less anxious.
Classified_Subsection: Progress Evaluation: History of Present Illness (HPI)

Utterance: That’s fantastic! Did you have a chance to express your feelings in a conversation?
Yes, I did! I talked to my friend about how I felt when we argued about plans.
How did that go?
It went really well. She listened, and we ended up having a really good conversation.
That’s wonderful! It sounds like your practice is paying off. What did you learn from that experience?
I learned that it’s okay to be vulnerable. It actually brought us closer.
That’s a significant realization. Vulnerability can strengthen connections. How does that make you feel about future conversations?
I feel more confident now. I think I can express myself more often.
That’s a great shift in perspective. Are there any challenges you’re still facing?
I still struggle with guilt about my bird. It lingers sometimes.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: It’s normal for those feelings to come and go. Have you found any strategies that help you cope with that guilt?
I’ve been trying to remind myself that I did what I thought was best at the time.
That’s a healthy approach. It’s important to be compassionate towards yourself. Would you like to explore ways to honor your bird’s memory?
Yes, I think that could help.
One idea could be to create a small ritual or a memory space for your bird. What do you think?
That sounds nice. Maybe I could plant a flower or something in its memory.
That’s a beautiful idea. It could be a way to celebrate its life while also allowing you to process your feelings. How does that resonate with you?
It feels comforting. I like the idea of having a place to remember it.
I’m glad to hear that. Would you like to set a goal around creating that memory space?
Yes, I’ll aim to do that by next month.
That sounds perfect. As we continue to work on your feelings of guilt and your relationships, is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
I’ve been thinking about my family dynamics. I still feel torn between wanting to spend time with them and needing my own space.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That’s a common struggle. How do you currently navigate that balance?
I often end up giving in to their needs, even when I need time alone.
It sounds like you’re putting others before yourself. Would you like to explore ways to communicate your needs to your family?
Yes, I think that would be helpful.
One approach could be to set boundaries. Have you ever tried discussing your need for personal time with them?
Not really. I worry they might take it personally.
That’s understandable. It might help to frame it as a way for you to recharge so you can be more present when you are with them. Would you feel comfortable trying that?
I think I could try that. I want them to understand that it’s not about them.
That’s a great mindset. Setting boundaries can be a healthy way to maintain relationships. How do you feel about taking that step?
I feel nervous, but I also think it’s necessary.
It is necessary for your well-being. Remember, it’s okay to prioritize yourself. What’s one thing you can do this week to start that conversation?
I could talk to my mom this weekend about needing some time for myself.
That sounds like a good plan. How do you feel about approaching that conversation?
A bit anxious, but I think it’s time.
It is time. You’re making great strides in your self-awareness and communication. As we wrap up today, what’s one takeaway you’d like to carry with you?
I want to focus on being honest about my needs, both with myself and my family.
That’s a powerful takeaway. I’m proud of the progress you’re making. I look forward to hearing how it goes next time. Take care!
Thank you, Ellie. I appreciate your support. See you next time!
